**Gabrielle Mary Hoffmann** (born January 8, 1982) is an American film and
television actress best known for her roles on _[Sleepless in
Seattle](/wiki/Sleepless_in_Seattle_\(film\) "Sleepless in Seattle
\(film\)"),_ _[Transparent](/wiki/Transparent_\(TV_series\) "Transparent \(TV
series\)")_ and _[Girls](/wiki/Girls_\(TV_series\) "Girls \(TV series\)")_
,[3] which garnered her nominations for the [Primetime Emmy Award for
Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Comedy
Series](/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Award_for_Outstanding_Supporting_Actress_in_a_Comedy_Series
"Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Comedy Series")
and [Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actress in a Comedy
Series](/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Award_for_Outstanding_Guest_Actress_in_a_Comedy_Series
"Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actress in a Comedy Series") in
2015, respectively.[4] Additionally, she is remembered as a child actress from
the films _[Field of Dreams](/wiki/Field_of_Dreams "Field of Dreams")_ ,
_[Uncle Buck](/wiki/Uncle_Buck "Uncle Buck")_ , _[Now and
Then](/wiki/Now_and_Then_\(1995_film\) "Now and Then \(1995 film\)")_, and
_[Volcano](/wiki/Volcano_\(1997_film\) "Volcano \(1997 film\)")_.[5]

## Early
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gaby_Hoffmann&action=edit&section=1&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Early life")]

Hoffmann was born in [Manhattan, New York City](/wiki/Manhattan,_New_York_City
"Manhattan, New York City"), [New York](/wiki/New_York_\(state\) "New York
\(state\)"). Her mother, [Viva](/wiki/Viva_\(actress\) "Viva \(actress\)")
(born Janet Susan Mary Hoffmann),[6] is an actress, writer and former [Warhol
superstar](/wiki/Warhol_superstars "Warhol superstars"),[7] and her father,
[Anthony Herrera](/wiki/Anthony_Herrera "Anthony Herrera"),[8] was a [soap
opera](/wiki/Soap_opera "Soap opera") actor best known for his role as [James
Stenbeck](/wiki/James_Stenbeck "James Stenbeck") from _[As the World
Turns](/wiki/As_the_World_Turns "As the World Turns")_.[9] Viva and Herrera
were estranged shortly after Hoffmann's birth; she was raised by her mother at
the [Chelsea Hotel](/wiki/Hotel_Chelsea "Hotel Chelsea") in New York. Her
father did not have a significant presence in her life.[10][11] Hoffmann's
birth is documented in [Brigid Berlin](/wiki/Brigid_Berlin "Brigid Berlin")'s
_The Andy Warhol Diaries_. An entry dated January 10, 1982, two days after
Hoffmann was born, says that a friend of Warhol's telephoned Warhol and told
him that they were going to the Chelsea Hotel to see Viva and her new baby.

Hoffmann's mother was raised in a devout [Catholic](/wiki/Catholicism
"Catholicism") family[11] on [Long Island](/wiki/Long_Island "Long Island"),
the daughter of an attorney.[12][13] She was previously married to director
[Michel Auder](/wiki/Michel_Auder "Michel Auder") in 1969. Gaby has a half-
sister, Alexandra "Alex" Auder, who is 11 years older.[14] Auder teaches yoga
in New York City.[15] Hoffmann's father was raised in
[Wiggins](/wiki/Wiggins,_Mississippi "Wiggins, Mississippi"),
[Mississippi](/wiki/Mississippi "Mississippi") by his maternal grandparents;
his own father, Gaby's biological great-grandfather was referenced, viewed,
and stated on the PBS series, Finding Your Roots with Henry Louis Gates Jr.
Season 4, Episode 8, to be Gaston L Malecot. An instructor at Columbia
University and a World War 1 veteran.[1] Herrera died in 2011 from cancer.[9]

Hoffmann attended elementary school in Manhattan at P.S. 3 on Hudson Street in
the [West Village](/wiki/West_Village "West Village"), then another school in
[Hell's Kitchen](/wiki/Hell%27s_Kitchen "Hell's Kitchen"). After she moved to
Los Angeles in 1994, she attended the [Buckley
School](/wiki/Buckley_School_\(California\) "Buckley School \(California\)"),
before finally graduating from [Calabasas High
School](/wiki/Calabasas_High_School "Calabasas High School") in 1999.[2]

### Life at the Chelsea
Hotel[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gaby_Hoffmann&action=edit&section=2&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Life at the Chelsea Hotel")]

Until July 1993, Hoffmann lived in Manhattan's Chelsea Hotel (now a landmark),
which Hoffmann later said she enjoyed. According to Hoffmann, she and her best
friend Talya Shomron would roller-skate in the hallways, spy on the drug
dealer across the hall, and persuade the [bellman](/wiki/Bellhop "Bellhop") to
go to the neighborhood [delicatessen](/wiki/Delicatessen "Delicatessen") at
night to fetch them ice cream.[10]

Hoffmann recalled, "I grew up in downtown New York in the '80s. I have a
friend who grew up with me, and she puts it well. She says, 'If you grew up
where we grew up, if you weren't an artist, a [drag queen](/wiki/Drag_queen
"Drag queen"), [queer](/wiki/Queer "Queer"), or a drug addict, then you were
the freak [unusual one].' I grew up in a world where I guess what is
considered unusual or abnormal for the rest of America was very much
considered the norm."[3] She also reported in an interview that there had been
gunfire and a rape at the hotel shortly before they moved out of it.[11]

Hoffmann and her mother left the Chelsea Hotel after a long-standing dispute
with the management that ended in eviction.[11] Regardless, Gaby's connection
to the hotel resulted in a significant effect on her future. The idea for the
1994 sitcom _[Someone Like Me](/wiki/Someone_Like_Me "Someone Like Me")_
originated after [Gail Berman](/wiki/Gail_Berman "Gail Berman") (former
president of [Viacom](/wiki/Viacom "Viacom")'s [Paramount
Pictures](/wiki/Paramount_Pictures "Paramount Pictures")) read a _[New York
Times](/wiki/New_York_Times "New York Times")_ article[14] about the hotel
which referred to a children's book that Viva and friend Jane Lancellotti
wrote, _Gaby at the Chelsea_ (a take on [Kay Thompson](/wiki/Kay_Thompson "Kay
Thompson")'s 1950s classic [Eloise](/wiki/Eloise_\(books\) "Eloise \(books\)")
books). Berman became the [show's producer](/wiki/Television_producer
"Television producer").

### Adolescence on the West
Coast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gaby_Hoffmann&action=edit&section=3&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Adolescence on the West Coast")]

When Hoffmann was 11, after leaving the Chelsea,[2] Hoffmann and her mother
moved to the west coast to a two-bedroom rented house in [Woodland
Hills](/wiki/Woodland_Hills,_Los_Angeles,_California "Woodland Hills, Los
Angeles, California"), [Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles"),
[California](/wiki/California "California"), which was badly damaged in the
January 17, [1994 Northridge earthquake](/wiki/1994_Northridge_earthquake
"1994 Northridge earthquake"). While regrouping their living situation, Gaby
and her mother temporarily lived at The Oceana Suites Hotel in [Santa Monica,
California](/wiki/Santa_Monica,_California "Santa Monica,
California").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### College and assorted
jobs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gaby_Hoffmann&action=edit&section=4&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: College and assorted jobs")]

After she graduated from [Calabasas High School](/wiki/Calabasas_High_School
"Calabasas High School") in 1999, Hoffmann followed her half-sister Alex's
example and entered New York's [Bard College](/wiki/Bard_College "Bard
College") to pursue a degree in literature and writing.[11] Around 2001, she
temporarily left her acting career to complete her studies and graduated in
2004; her senior thesis was a [documentary film](/wiki/Documentary_film
"Documentary film").[11]

After college, she spent much of her 20s drifting. She interned with a chef in
Italy, and then trained to be a [doula](/wiki/Doula "Doula") after helping
deliver Alex's children. For a time, Hoffmann and a boyfriend lived in an old
trailer in the [Catskill Mountains](/wiki/Catskill_Mountains "Catskill
Mountains").[14]

##
Career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gaby_Hoffmann&action=edit&section=5&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Career")]

### Childhood acting
career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gaby_Hoffmann&action=edit&section=6&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Childhood acting career")]

Hoffmann began her acting career at the age of four to help pay the family
bills by acting in commercials. In 1989, she starred in her first movie,
_[Field of Dreams](/wiki/Field_of_Dreams "Field of Dreams"),_ with [Kevin
Costner](/wiki/Kevin_Costner "Kevin Costner"). 1989's _[Uncle
Buck](/wiki/Uncle_Buck "Uncle Buck")_ followed, working beside [John
Candy](/wiki/John_Candy "John Candy") and up-and-coming child star [Macaulay
Culkin](/wiki/Macaulay_Culkin "Macaulay Culkin"). However, she grew tired of
the rigors of screen performance and temporarily retired. Nevertheless, upon
hearing that Culkin (whom she disliked when they worked together[11]) was
making a lot of money in feature films, her "competitive spirit got the best
of her," as she later put it, and she re-entered the profession. She went on
to star in _[This Is My Life](/wiki/This_Is_My_Life_\(1992_film\) "This Is My
Life \(1992 film\)")_ (1992), _[Sleepless in
Seattle](/wiki/Sleepless_in_Seattle "Sleepless in Seattle")_ (1993) with [Tom
Hanks](/wiki/Tom_Hanks "Tom Hanks") and _[The Man Without a
Face](/wiki/The_Man_Without_a_Face "The Man Without a Face")_ with [Mel
Gibson](/wiki/Mel_Gibson "Mel Gibson") (who also directed the film).[16]
According to Hoffmann, it was the praise she received for her performance in
_This is My Life_ which encouraged her to pursue a full-time acting career in
Hollywood as it gave her the confidence she needed to handle major roles.[16]

In 1994, Hoffmann was given the starring role in her own sitcom _[Someone Like
Me](/wiki/Someone_Like_Me_\(TV_series\) "Someone Like Me \(TV series\)")_ (on
[NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC")) about a young girl, Gaby, and her dysfunctional
family. Although generally well received, the show only lasted six episodes.
Publicity work for the show included personal appearances by Hoffmann on late
night talk shows like _[The Tonight Show with Jay
Leno](/wiki/The_Tonight_Show_with_Jay_Leno "The Tonight Show with Jay Leno")_
and _[Late Show with David Letterman](/wiki/Late_Show_with_David_Letterman
"Late Show with David Letterman")_.

After _Someone Like Me_ , Hoffmann won the lead role opposite [Shelley
Long](/wiki/Shelley_Long "Shelley Long") in the 1995 TV film _[Freaky
Friday](/wiki/Freaky_Friday_\(1995_film\) "Freaky Friday \(1995 film\)")_ , a
remake of the [1976 film of the same name](/wiki/Freaky_Friday_\(1976_film\)
"Freaky Friday \(1976 film\)") starring [Jodie Foster](/wiki/Jodie_Foster
"Jodie Foster") and [Barbara Harris](/wiki/Barbara_Harris_\(actress\) "Barbara
Harris \(actress\)"). In the same year as _Freaky Friday_ , Hoffmann starred
as Young Samantha (the childhood counterpart to [Demi Moore](/wiki/Demi_Moore
"Demi Moore")'s character) in the coming-of-age feature film, _[Now and
Then](/wiki/Now_and_Then_\(film\) "Now and Then \(film\)")_.

In 1995, Hoffmann played Andrea Eagerton in the [CBS](/wiki/CBS "CBS") TV film
_Whose Daughter Is She?_.

### Teen and college years:
1996–2003[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gaby_Hoffmann&action=edit&section=7&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Teen and college years: 1996–2003")]

Between 1996 and 2001, Hoffmann landed roles in several films including
_[Everyone Says I Love You](/wiki/Everyone_Says_I_Love_You "Everyone Says I
Love You")_ (1996), _[Volcano](/wiki/Volcano_\(1997_film\) "Volcano \(1997
film\)")_ (1997), _[Snapped](/wiki/Snapped "Snapped")_ (1998), _[The Hairy
Bird](/wiki/The_Hairy_Bird "The Hairy Bird")_ (1998), _[200
Cigarettes](/wiki/200_Cigarettes "200 Cigarettes")_ (1999), _[Coming
Soon](/wiki/Coming_Soon_\(1999_film\) "Coming Soon \(1999 film\)")_ (1999),
_[Black& White](/wiki/Black_and_White_\(1999_drama_film\) "Black and White
\(1999 drama film\)")_ (1999), _[You Can Count on
Me](/wiki/You_Can_Count_on_Me "You Can Count on Me")_ (2000), and
_[Perfume](/wiki/Perfume_\(2001_film\) "Perfume \(2001 film\)")_ (2001).

### Theatre work in New York:
2003–2007[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gaby_Hoffmann&action=edit&section=8&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Theatre work in New York: 2003–2007")]

Between 2003 and 2007, Hoffmann largely concentrated on a theatre career in
New York. Roles included _24 Hour Plays_ (as Denise at the American Airlines
Theatre), _[The Sugar Syndrome](/wiki/The_Sugar_Syndrome "The Sugar
Syndrome")_ (Williamstown Theatre Festival – July/August 2005), and _Third_
([Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater](/wiki/Mitzi_E._Newhouse_Theater "Mitzi E.
Newhouse Theater")/[Lincoln Center](/wiki/Lincoln_Center "Lincoln Center")
Theater – September – December 2005). In late 2005, she starred in an episode
of _[Law& Order: Criminal Intent](/wiki/Law_%26_Order:_Criminal_Intent "Law &
Order: Criminal Intent")_. She also appeared in the Broadway play
_[Suburbia](/wiki/Suburbia "Suburbia")_ , alongside [Kieran
Culkin](/wiki/Kieran_Culkin "Kieran Culkin") and [Jessica
Capshaw](/wiki/Jessica_Capshaw "Jessica Capshaw") at the Second Stage Theatre
on 43rd Street in New York City, which ran from September to October 2006.
Hoffmann then returned to the _24 Hours Plays_ where she acted alongside
[Jennifer Aniston](/wiki/Jennifer_Aniston "Jennifer Aniston").

### Return to film work:
2007–present[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gaby_Hoffmann&action=edit&section=9&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Return to film work: 2007–present")]

Since 2007, Hoffmann has made a gradual return to film acting. In 2007, she
starred in the film _Severed Ways: The Norse Discovery of America_. In 2008,
she appeared in _Guest of Cindy Sherman_ , a documentary on art-scene
commentator Paul Hasegawa-Overacker's relationship with enigmatic photographer
[Cindy Sherman](/wiki/Cindy_Sherman "Cindy Sherman"). Later in 2008, Hoffmann
appeared in the documentary _Chelsea on the Rocks_ , which is a tribute to the
Chelsea Hotel where she grew up. Directed by [Abel Ferrara](/wiki/Abel_Ferrara
"Abel Ferrara"), the documentary highlights the many personalities and
artistic voices that have emerged from the legendary residence.

In 2009, Hoffmann had a supporting role in [Todd Solondz](/wiki/Todd_Solondz
"Todd Solondz")'s _[Life During
Wartime](/wiki/Life_During_Wartime_\(2009_film\) "Life During Wartime \(2009
film\)")_ , and the thriller _[13](/wiki/13_\(2010_film\) "13 \(2010 film\)")_
with [Mickey Rourke](/wiki/Mickey_Rourke "Mickey Rourke") (released in 2010).

More recently, Hoffmann has starred alongside [Michael
Cera](/wiki/Michael_Cera "Michael Cera") in _[Crystal Fairy& the Magical
Cactus](/wiki/Crystal_Fairy_%26_the_Magical_Cactus "Crystal Fairy & the
Magical Cactus")_ (2013). While shooting the film in Chile, she and Cera took
[mescaline](/wiki/Mescaline "Mescaline") for her performance in a climactic
scene.[17]

Recent guest appearances have been in the television series
_[Louie](/wiki/Louie_\(U.S._TV_series\) "Louie \(U.S. TV series\)")_ and
_[Girls](/wiki/Girls_\(TV_series\) "Girls \(TV series\)")_ in Season 3.[18]
Hoffmann said that she will be coming back in season 4 of
_[Girls](/wiki/Girls_\(TV_series\) "Girls \(TV series\)")._[3]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Cast_of_Transparent.jpg/140px-
Cast_of_Transparent.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cast_of_Transparent.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cast_of_Transparent.jpg "Enlarge")

Hoffmann (bottom left). She is seen here with fellow cast members of
_[Transparent](/wiki/Transparent_\(TV_series\) "Transparent \(TV series\)")_
in 2015

In 2013, she completed work on the lead role of a [Web
series](/wiki/Web_series "Web series") entitled _Lyle_ , created by Stewart
Thorndike and [Jill Soloway](/wiki/Jill_Soloway "Jill Soloway"). It was shot
in NYC. She subsequently acquired an apartment in Brooklyn's [Fort
Greene](/wiki/Fort_Greene "Fort Greene") section.[14] In October 2013, she
starred in the 1910s installment of Vanity Fair's _The Decades Series_ , "The
First March", directed by Gilly Barnes.[19]

Hoffmann has discussed her full frontal nude scenes in a few of her recent
projects including _Crystal Fairy_ , _Girls_ and the [Amazon](/wiki/Amazon.com
"Amazon.com") series _[Transparent](/wiki/Transparent_\(TV_series\)
"Transparent \(TV series\)")._[20] On nudity, Hoffmann said: "People are
obsessed with actresses being hairless, fatless Barbie dolls. They can’t
imagine that people would want to be anything other than that. When they are,
it's looked at as almost a political statement. Look at [Lena
Dunham](/wiki/Lena_Dunham "Lena Dunham"). She is a gorgeous woman and people
can't stop talking about how brave she is to show herself naked, which I find
totally condescending and ridiculous. If [Angelina Jolie](/wiki/Angelina_Jolie
"Angelina Jolie") was naked onscreen no one would say she was brave. The
implication is that Lena's brave because she doesn't look the way she's
supposed to look. I think that's a shame."[21]

[Jill Soloway](/wiki/Jill_Soloway "Jill Soloway") wrote the role Hoffmann
plays in _[Transparent](/wiki/Transparent_\(TV_series\) "Transparent \(TV
series\)")_ for her after seeing her performance on [Louis
C.K.](/wiki/Louis_C.K. "Louis C.K.")'s third season of
_[Louie](/wiki/Louie_\(U.S._TV_series\) "Louie \(U.S. TV series\)")._[22]

In 2016 she appeared in video as an onstage "stand-in" during the [Nostalgic
For the Present](/wiki/Nostalgic_for_the_Present_Tour "Nostalgic for the
Present Tour") concert tour of Australian singer [Sia Furler](/wiki/Sia_Furler
"Sia Furler") for her song, "Unstoppable."[23]

## Personal
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gaby_Hoffmann&action=edit&section=10&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Personal life")]

Hoffmann has a daughter, Rosemary,[24] born in November 2014, with longtime
boyfriend, cinematographer Chris Dapkins (born on November 19,
1980).[25][26][27] She lives in the [Fort Greene](/wiki/Fort_Greene,_Brooklyn
"Fort Greene, Brooklyn") neighborhood of [Brooklyn](/wiki/Brooklyn,_New_York
"Brooklyn, New York").[21]
